posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
Since it appears you are focusing primarily on the arcane-based variety...

Mith's singing scyther aka. Ruinous Raconteur has given me some mileage albeit tweaked a bit to adapt to the specific magic environment of choice. The weapon itself is subject to personal preference but with the 2-hand-wielding weapon being the unifying constant among classical spellswords, scythe always works for me. And the slash/pierce combo damage has an advantage at times.

Still, in general, divine spellswords rule... but are commonly tagged with the nom de plume of "battle cleric". If it smells like uber-buffed two-handed big weapon melee, whether arcane or divine, it becomes a double threat on most servers regardless of magical discipline and the gods' glance.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
conlaoch wrote:-- clip--
I'm too used to using magic to blast things.
-- clip --
...then perhaps what would float your builder's boat the best would be a Melee Mage rather than a spellsword.

WebShaman pretty much perfected an approach for "blasters" to retain a significant melee presence while still empowered with all the arcane goodness characteristic of those godly high-level casters. It does require some pre-planning to optimize the build's advantages, though. Web's original build post itself contains a lot of strategy type information that is generally useful to all aspiring arcanists.

On the other hand, a spellsword is primarily a self-buffer, typically manning a greatsword, that maintains enough casting prowess to be considered an effective hybrid of both attacks but with the spell DC as a secondary consideration. At least that has been my interpretation of the term "spellsword", though if Web had joined the new ECB, his perspective would be invaluable as a standing resource.

The particular weapon and minimum number of caster levels (at least 24 are needed to shrug off most dispels) can vary, but the self-buffing combat methodology of a spellsword does not (or should not... for comparison's sake, that is).

Yeah, I like the melee mage tract, but I find myself using summons ore often then melee when I have that many caster levels. I mainly play on WoG, and a crafted wand always has 50 charges. Kind of hard to do the melee mage thing when I have a wand of summon IV for a quick 50 minions.

I think my fascination with Spellswords came from learning to play D&D from the old blue box set (giving away my age there). An elf was an automatic spellsword. Slower exp progression, but warrior and mage all wrapped in one.

Most of the time when I make a spellsword, it has 24-26 mage levels although the version above with sorc 20/CoT10/PM10 is real fun once the pale master crit immunity kicks in.

With a spellsword you can not get everything. And you will never get a build that is as strong a warrior or mage as a specialized build can be. Spellswords are difficult to build because there are so many things you may want to focus on, and you don't have the resources to spread out on everything.
I ended up building the Spellsword of Bahamut to get what I wanted from a spellsword. If you read the thread you will also find some links to other builds that I like, or that have influenced the build.
